title: What do you know about food waste?
teaser: Read the most interesting facts about Food Waste

content.text: There is enough food produced in the world to feed everyone.
content.source: 2016 World Hunger and Poverty Facts and Statistics

content.text: One third of all food produced is lost or wasted – around 1.3 billion tonnes of food – costing the global economy close to $940 billion each year.
content.source: FAO Save Food Global Food Waste and Loss Initiative

content.text: Up to 10% of global greenhouse gases comes from food that is produced, but not eaten.
content.source: United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) (2021). Food Waste Index Report 2021.

content.text: Wasting food is worse than total emissions from flying (1.9%), plastic production (3.8%) and oil extraction (3.8%).
If food waste was a country, it would be the third biggest emitter of greenhouse gases after USA and China.
Food rotting in landfill releases methane – 28x stronger than carbon dioxide.
content.source: IPCC Special Report on Climate Change and Land

content.text: Eliminating global food waste would save 4.4 million tonnes of CO2 a year, the equivalent of taking one in four cars off the road.
One in nine people do not have enough food to eat, that’s 793 million people who are undernourished.
content.source: FAO The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2015

content.text: If one quarter of the food currently lost or wasted could be saved, it would be enough to feed 870 million hungry people.
content.source: FAO The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2015

content.text: Almost half of all fruit and vegetables produced are wasted (that’s 3.7 trillion apples).
content.source: FAO Infographic – Global Initiative on Food Loss and Waste Reduction

content.text: Throwing away one burger wastes the same amount of water as a 90-minute shower.
It takes 25 years for a head of lettuce to decompose in landfill.
content.source: Wasted! The Story of Food Waste film.

content.text: But the good news is, reducing food waste is the most effective thing individuals can do to address climate change.
